To secure quick transmission, telegrams should be marked Via Eastern.
For latest average time to London, see daily bulletin in this paper.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Berths can be definitely engaged as if the vayoage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles, Gibralter, Plymouth, and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamer leaves Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before.
The express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Wednesday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m. and arriving in London at the very convenient hour of 4.56 p.m. On Friday.
The combined Sea and special train fare is £22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindisi or via Marseilles:
The Sea fares are:-
In addition to the above regular weekly service there are sailing about twice a fortnight of 5,000 to 7,000 tons steamers to London, calling at Malta or Marseilles.

div.head: TO THE EAST
div.p: The Mail Steamers leave Suez for Adem and Bombay every Wednesday, and for Australia and China every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for Calcutta, fortnightly, and another for Japan. Passengers can embark at Port Said.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,

div.head: THE MUSEUM OF ANTIQUITIES.
div.p: All most acknowledge the immense amount of care and labour expended by Professor Maspero and his staff in successfully moving a vast mass of antiquities from Ghizeh to the new museum without the loss or injury of a single object of importance, and in arranging them. The achievement was most remarkable; it demands and deserves the sincere homage of all who can realise the difficulties and the risks involved in so great an undertak- ing. But there is a certain incomplete- ness, a something lacking in the new Museum of Antiquities. The building, the antiquities, the staff of the Service — all are there, but we miss the educational functions of a museum, and their absence inspires the present criticism, made with no intention of mere fault-finding or causing pain to officials who have laboured strenuously in the cause of Egyptology, but rather to point out to the authorities the right way to make the museum more interesting and of greater value to the world than is the case at present.

What is the purpose of a museum? Is it merely a safe in which curious or valuable objects are preserved, or is it an educational institution appealing, it is true, more to those already instructed than to the general public, but educational in its functions none the less? We oould not justify the large sums of public money, that have been expended on the museum building if this were not the case, and it is only on such grounds that the annual grant of public funds to the Antiquities Department can be justified. But, if the object of the museum is educational, why is so little done to fulfil it? Why is the museum so useless for purposes of study, so poorly equipped for them in comparison with all the first-class collections of the Continent and Great Britain? What other museum but pos- sesses a large stock of folly descriptive labels attached to all important objects, whether they be Greek vases, rare lepidoptera, or unique geological specimens?

We may be referred to the catalogue, but the small catalogue does little but give the visitor who chooses to buy it a. superficial idea of the general arrangement of the objects while the great catalogue—a monumental work— is so vast, so cumbersome, and so expensive as to be inaccessible to the majority. Descrip- tive labels are entirely lacking in some cases, while in others the objects are provided with cards bearing perhaps the name of a king or a dynasty. But this is not enough. How can comparative study be carried on unless we are told whence an object comes, and of what it is a part. A statue or a piece of sculpture bearing the name of Thothmes III. may come from anywhere between Dongola and the Mediterranean, but the cards are dumb.

And this neglect is worse than unwise, it is not business when it affects a series of objects which the museum may owe to the special liberality of donors, among whom we include those who pay the cost of special excavations. Would it not be well, pour en- courager les autres, to give their names, and to provide fully descriptive labels for the objects which their efforts or their money have caused to be brought to light? All who have the pleasure of knowing the genial and kindly Director of the Department of Antiquities must realise that this neglect to which we call attention is due to forgetfulness, and could never arise from any desire to overlook or to exclude what we venture to claim as no more than a public right.

The London and North Western Railway (England), after exhaustive trials and mature experience, have decided, not only to equip all the new rolling stock they build with Stone’s System of Electric Lighting but they have also abandoned the use of oil gas and dismantled the gas fittings from over 1,100 carriages and substituted in place of same Stone's System of Electric Lighting. This change has already been made, with results entirely satisfactory both to the travelling public and to the Railway Company. This Railway Company alone has 4,000 carriages of all types (from ordinary suburban carriages to their latest type of dining and sleeping saloons) fitted with Stone's System of Electric Lighting and Ventilating.

div.head: NAVAL BATTLE AT SEVASTOPOL. HALF CITY DEMOLISHED, MUTINY AT LIBAU

div.p: The "Slovo” states that a naval battle took place on Tuesday at Sevastopol. It lasted two hours. The rebel ships opened fire on the forts. The cruiser Otchakoff was pierced and burst into flames; the cruiser Dnieper, another ship, and several torpedo-boats were sunk. Lieutenant Schmidt, chief of the rebels, having been killed, the squadron surrendered. Half the city of Sevastopol is demolished.
A grave mutiny has broken out at Liban, and another is feared at Kronstadt. (Reuter)

Another account of the battle at Sevastopol is that the mutineers lost heart when a rebel torpedo-boat was sunk and two cruisers damaged. They endeavoured to make the shore in boats, but were intercepted by the loyal torpedo-boats. Meanwhile; the loyal Bielostock Regiment attacked the barracks held by the mutinous seamen, 1,500 of whom surrendered with 10 Maxims, owing to the attitude of the Naval Battalions.
Disarmed reservists are parading the streets at Nijni Novgorod singing revolutionary songs.
Reservists at Doinsk have unanimously resolved not to take the oath if called out. The resolution has been printed and distributed broadcast.
110.000 men are either locked out or on strike here, and 58,700 at Moscow. (Reuter)
There has been a battle between the rebels and the Royalist troops. Half of the city is destroyed. The mutineers were defeated and surrendered. Lieutenant Schmidt is fatally wounded.(Havas)

div.head: A ROYAL PASSIVE RESISTER. The Sultan and the Powers.
div.p: The Sultan persists in his resistance. The international squadron is preparing to occupy another island. (Havas)

div.head: THE CRETAN GARRISON NO GREEK TROOPS.
div.p: The Government has announced in the Chamber that the Powers have unanimously refused to substitute Greek troops for the international force at present in Crete. (Reuter)

div.head: The Mail.
div.p: The Brindisi mail will close at the G.P.O., Alexandria, at 3.30 p.m. on Sunday.

div.head: Ministry of Justice.
div.p: Two buildings for housing judges and inspectors are to be built by the Ministry of Justice at Tantah.

div.head: Death from Intoxication.
div.p: A native, aged 20, was found dead at Kom El Milh, in the Karmous district, yesterday. The body was taken to hospital, where the post-mortem examination proved that death was due to intoxication.

div.head: Queen's Birthday.
div.p: To-day, on the occasion of the 61st birthday of H.M. Queen Alexandra, H.M.S, Carnarvon dressed ship and flew the Royal Standard. The Royal Standard is also flying over Port Kom el Nadonrs.

div.head: French Operettas
div.p: The Crepy-Simon French operetta company will make its first appearance at the Alhambra Theatre, Alexandria, to-night, when Saltimbanque will be given. The operettas to be given include a number of novelties.

div.head: Suez Canal
div.p: Nineteen vessels passed through the Canal on the 26th and 27th, of which 12 were British, 2 German, 2 French, 2 Italian, 1 Russian. The total amount of receipts from the 1st to the 27th was frs. 8,839,169.03.

div.head: Found Drowned.
div.p: The dead body of a Swedish seaman (27) was found floating in Alexandria harbour yesterday near wharf No. 9, bearing marks of a slight injury to his chin. The body was taken out of the water and removed to the hospital for a post-mortem examination.

div.head: Arrivals.
div.p: The S.S. Portugal, of the Messageries Maritimes, has brought several professors from the Berlitz School of Paris, the number of the staff having been found insufficient to cope with the great demand for lessons; Cairo, 1, Sharia Kamel; Alexandria, 26, Rue de l'Eglise Copse.

div.head: New Commission House.
div.p: Messrs. Missak Moronkian & Co., brokers, of Smyrna, have opened a branch at Alexandria, at 3, rue Mehmoud Pashareal Falaki, which will undertake business in American and Egyptian cotton on the markets of New York and Liverpool and also in the stocks and shares on any Bourse. M. Mardick L. Baliozian will be in sole charge of the branch and will sign for the firm.

div.head: Lucky Cotton Speculator.
div.p: A sensational rise in the price of cotton has enabled Mr. Joseph Hoadley to make £200,000 in five minutes on the New York exchange. The market has expected 8,000,000 bales of cotton to be ginned up to Nov. 14, there were only 7,498,167 bales. There was a mad rush to buy; prices went up 20 points at a time. Then Mr. Hoadley turned seller. His total profits on the day's business are estimated at £800,000.

div.head: Post Office Notice.
div.p: Owing to the fact that former notices referring to clear direction of correspondence have been largely disregarded by the public and that the general delivery has had to be delayed in consequence, it has been decided that from 1st February 1906, correspondence for house to house delivery addressed only "Cairo" or "Alexandria" will be retarded and only sorted after the first delivery of each mail has left the post offices in those towns. After that date it will be no longer necessary to make special requests for house to house delivery as correspondence bearing the full address will be duly delivered.
Mr. Iddings, Diplomatic Agent and Consul General for the United States of America, and Mrs. Iddings, have left Cairo for a trip to Upper Egypt.

Rear-Admiral the Hon. Sir Hedworth Lambton, whose flagship, the Carnarvon, is now at Alexandria, had an interesting experience during the bombardment of Alexandria. He was the Admiral’s flag lieutenant during the bombardment and volunteered with a boat’s crew to spike the guns of the Mex fort. The sea being too rough to land they jumped into the sea, swam ashore, and successfully carried out their mission.

The family of Mme Vve Piha Bey wish to publicly thank Sisters Hetty Crowther and Martha Bacon, as well as the male nurse, Andrea J. Couroupis for their devoted attention to their late mother during her long illness.

The latest arrivals at Mena House include: Rear-Admiral Hon. H. Lambton, Sir George Warrender, R.N.. Mr. J. H. Livingston, Mrs. Geddies, Mrs. Williams, Miss M. Price, Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Kerr, the Misses Mulvany, Mr. W. Kidd, Mme Louise Ballusock, Miss Gunley, Miss Mulholland, Dr. Hastings, Mr. A. Denny, Miss Reid, Miss Schofield, Mr. and Mrs. E. Newman, Miss Newman, Mrs. Bullock, Miss McKellar, and Miss E. Baird.
Mr. E. Almaz Stout has contributed an excellent description of an Arab wedding in Cairo to the "Ladies' Field" of November 18.

div.head: OUR ROYAL VISITOR. ARRIVAL AT CAIRO.
div.p: H.H. Prince Leopold of Battenberg arrived at Port Said by the Orient steamer Ormuz and proceeded straight to Cairo.
Lord Cremer was present at Cairo station to bid his Royal Highness welcome. A suite of rooms has been engaged for him at the Hotel d'Angleterre.

div.head: LORD CROMER IN THE SUDAN.
div.p: We understand that Lord Cromer, after presiding over the official opening of the Nile- Red Sea Railway, will proceed by the line to Kharteum, whence he will made a trip up the White Nile before his return to Egypt. Lord Cromer is expected to be absent from Cairo a little over a month.

div.head: THE JUDICIAL CONFERENCE.
div.p: The International Commission of the Mixed Tribunals met on Wednesday at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, under the presidency of H.E. Boutros Pasha Ghali. We understand that the question of the unification of the bureaux for transcriptions of property, etc., was discussed, and that the Government proposals on this subject have been approved in principle by the Commission.

div.head: THE SUCRERIES.
div.p: The meeting of the creditors of the Sucreries Co., to hear the proposals of the controllers, takes place today at 3 p.m. It is stated that the directors of the Sucreries have protested by letter to Judge Tuck against certain statements which occur in the late report of the three experts. Meantime the judge is preparing his report on the concordst preventif granted to the company and may have completed it in time for this afternoon’s meeting.

div.head: ANGLO-AMERICAN COMPANY.
div.p: A rumour has been current in Cairo to the effect that Hanna Bey Bakoum will have some position in the Anglo-American and Hamburg- Amerika Companies amalgamation. The rumour, however, is baseless. A Cairo Bourne bulletin of yesterday’s date remarks :--

A propos da la farion de l’Anglo-American Nile avec la Hamburg-Amerika Linie, onrap- porte que Hanna bey Bakoum, administrateur de la Societe Tewfikieh, aurait offert a la Hamburg-Amerika “son concours et son influence en Egypte” a condition qu’elle venille bien faire l’acquisition de la Societe Tewfikieh. L’estimation de l’actif de la Societe Tewfikieh a donne lieu, l'annee passee, a des discussions plutot violeutes entre actionnaites et administrateurs, discussions dont la presse locale s’est longuement occupee. Quant a l’influence de M. Bakoum bey, elle a beaucoup perdu de sa valeur matchande a cette occasion. La transaction dont il est question pourra done, croyons- nous, se faire dans les prix deux.

div.head: MR. CHAMBERLAIN AND THE OCTROI.
div.p: Mr. Cooke, secretary of the Cheshire Liberal Unionist Association, recently directed Mr. Chamberlain’s attention to the fact that the removal of the octroi duties in Cairo made provisions dearer, proving Protection often cheapens and Free Trade raises prices to the consumer. Mr. Cooke also urged that the navigation laws required amendment. In his reply to Mr. Cooke, Mr. Chamberlain said he was in Cairo last year and could confirm the statement as to the effect of the octroi. He was also aware of the effect of the one- sided navigation laws, which undoubtedly tended to the disadvantage of British shipping in many cases.

div.head: NOTES FROM MENA.
div.p: The small dance given at Mena House Hotel was quite a success, and all the visitors staying there took part in it. The band was excellent, the floor in perfect condition, and last, but not least, the buffet everything one could desire. We noticed among the numerous visiters now staying at Mena House Hotel the following residents : H.E. Mustapha Pasha Fehmy, Sir Vincent Corbett, Mr. H Carter Wilson, Mr. and Mrs. Rowlatt, Mr. Easton Cornish. Mr. and Mrs. P. P. Peake, Dr. and Mrs. Hayward, Miss Weinberg, R Owen Bey, Mr. and Mrs. W. Chatterton Adams, Mr. de Bilinski, Miss de Bilinski, Col. and Mrs. Gordon, Major- Palmer, Capt. Brakenridge, Capt. Beamish, Capt. Grant, Capt. D. Parsons, Bimbashi Hughes, Mr. R. H. Duke, Mr. and Mrs. Archibald, Miss Miles, Mr. R. B. Paten, Hamza Bey Fehmin, Mr. A. E. Ross, and others, including Admiral Hom H. Lambton and Sir George Warrender.
There will be a band performing at Mena House Hotel on Sunday next during lunch from 1 to 2 o'clock, and from 3.30 to 5 o’clock in the afternoon.

div.head: EDEN PALACE HOTEL, Cairo
div.p: NOTED FOR ITS EXCELLENT CUISINE.
Electric Light, Lift
Special terms for officers of the Army of Occupation and Government Officials.

div.head: THE GHIZEH ACCIDENT SYPHON WRECKED.
div.p: It now appears that the total length of bank that collapsed between Ghizeh and Hawamdieh did not exceed 20 metres. The basin, which most have contained some 230,000,000 cubic metres of water, has been emptying itself into the Nile, carrying away some minor irrigation works and wrecking the syphon under the Ghizeh Canal.

A report was circulated in Cairo yesterday evening that the foundations of the masonry work of the bridge showed signs of having sustained some damage, threatening to prolong the delay to traffic with Upper Egypt.

The rumour arose from the fact that the earth fillings of the approaches to the bridge had given way. The Railway Administration is in consequence laying rails across an iron bridge close to the old wooden bridge which has been injured.
The washout is causing great inconvenience. Our Minieh Correspondent, writing under yesterday’s date, states that the night express was eight hours late at Minieh yesterday and the day before.

div.head: NEW BANK FOR EGYPTIAN AFFAIRS.
div.p: The Constantinople correspondent of the “Frankfurter Zeitung” learns the Dresdner Bank, the National Bank fuer Deutschland, and the Schaffenhauser Bankverein have formed a new bank, with headquarters in Berlin, to carry on business in Egypt and other Mediterranean countries now served by the Orient Bank of Athens, which was founded last spring by the National Bank. The Constantinople branch of the Orient Bank will be included in the new organization.

div.head: BANK OF ABYSSINIA.
div.p: Mr. Goldie, who is to manage the Harrar branch of the Bank of Abyssinia, left Cairo for Suez on Wednesday, and on Thursday morning Mr. MacGillivray left amid the farewells of a great number of friends who had come to the station to see him off. Sir Elwin Palmer, who was also at the station, presided over a banquet given in Mr. MacGillivray's honor on Wednesday night, at which he proposed the health of the head of the new bank and referred in warm terms to his character and abilities. Some twenty of Mr. MacGillivray's friends were present on the occasion, and he was the recipient of numerous wishes for his safety and success in his new post.
On his departure Mr. MacGillivray was presented by a deputation of the members of the Cairo Bourse with a splendid tea service as a memento of the part he played as one of its founders.

div.head: GERMAN TRADE WITH EGYPT.
div.p: A Consular report just published in Berlin shows a continued large increase of German trade with Egypt. In the ten years to 1904 the exports from Germany to Egypt have increased by £750,000, the totals being £350,000 in 1894 and £1,100,000 in 1904.

The German coal depots, established at Port Said to compete with the British coal depots, are doing a large trade, and are extremely prosperous. The export of German coal to Egypt reached a total of 63,000 tons last year.

During 1904 seventy German ships, of an aggregate tonnage of 150,000, touched at Alexandria. The Hamburg-Amerika Line is starting a steamship service to the Nile, by means of which it is expected that German trade with the interior will be considerably increased. German trade in Egypt is carried on by a German colony of 1,300 persons, of whom 600 live at Alexandria, and 500 in Cairo.

div.head: DAIRA SANIEH LOAN.
div.p: Yesterday was the last day for the presentation for payment in London of all outstanding bonds and coupons of the Daira Sanieh Four per Cent. Loan, in accordance with the notice issued by the controllers, dated July 21st, 1905. From to-day all such payments will be made in Cairo.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Messageries Maritimes S.S. Congo arrived at Marseille from Alexandria on Wednesday.
The S.S. Alexandria (Papayanni Line) left Malta yesterday and is expected to arrive at this port on Monday morning.
The Moss liner Rameses sailed from Malta yesterday afternoon and is due here on Sunday afternoon, with passengers, mails, and general cargo.
The Moss liner Khephren passed Holyhead yesterday for Liverpool.
Anglo-American Nile Steamer & Hotel Company
River Transport of Good Between Alexandria & Cairo
Three Sailings a-Week.

div.head: TWO RECENT WORKS UPON EGYPTIAN NUMISMATICS.
div.p: M. George Dattari, of Cairo, whose cabinet of coins is so celebrated among numismatists, has recently presented a paper to the Antiquarian and Nomismatic Society of Montreal, Canada referring to the celebrated statue of Serapis, by Bryaxis. The raison d'etre of this monograph is the deciding of the date of the statue’s arrival at Alexandria, which M. Dattari succeeds in achieving by means of evidence derived from coins the effigies upon which be considers completely settle the question. When the essay is printed in extenso, we hope to be permitted to publish a oomplete summary of its contents.

Another and longer treatise of M. Dattari may be found in that most excellent work the “Journal International d’Archeologie Numismatique" of Athens. It contains the learned author’s comments upon a board of Athenian tetradrachms found in Egypt. The thesis is as follows. The Saitic dynasty to secure Egyptian independence hired Greek mercenaries and the Mendesian dynasty to oppose the Persians went further, concluding an alliance with Macedonia and Athens. From this period Macedonian and Athenian coins are common in Egypt Tachos of the 30th dynasty employed 90,000 Greek troops, and to pay the expense of his Persian war he ordered his subject's to deposit all their gold and silver in the Treasury.

From his time Athenian tetradrachms are plentiful, but they are in most cases of very inferior workmanship compared to the splendid specimens of Athenian coinage. Athens at this time was wealthy and powerful and her coinage practically international in the Greek world. M. Dietary argues from the coins that Tachos struck “Athenian" tetradrachms here, and absolutely proves his case by producing a photograph of the die employed, which was found in Egypt with the hoard of tetradrachms, which are beautifully illustrated in prototype plates accompanying the essay. M. Dattari thinks Egypt imitated other Greek coins, but reserves his remarks upon this for another occasion.

div.head: CHRISTMAS MAILS.
div.p: Our readers will no doubt be interested to know that the latest time for posting parcels for the United Kingdom, so as to reach their destination by Christmas, is 6p.m. to-morrow for Alexandria, the mail leaving Port Said on Sunday, via Gibraltar. If sent by overland mail, parcels may be dispatched from Alexandria on the 8th December, or the 11th from Port Said. The latest date for posting letters for Christmas is 16th December, and for the New year, 23rd December. Parcels for Europe (not including the UK) should be sent a week earlier.

div.head: ANTI-TUBERCULOSIS LEAGUE.
div.p: The committee of the Anti-Tuberculosis League sent to the Grand Master of Ceremonies of H.H. the Khedive the balance sheet of the sociey and the reports of Drs. Legrand and Valassopoulo, its delegates at the Paris Inter- national Congress. In reply the Grand Master of Ceremonies, H.E. Ahmed Zeky Pashs, has sent the following letter to Dr. Sohiess Bey, chairman of the committee:--
Monsieur le President
J'ai eu l'honneur de soumettre a Son Altesse le Khedive les documents concernant la ligue contre la tuberculose.
Son Altesse me charge de vous remercier de cet envoi et de vous exprimer sa satisfaction pour l'activite si devouee que votre ligue ne cesse de deployer pour arriver a son but.
Veuillez agreer, Monsieur le President, l'as- surance de ma consideration tres distinguee.

div.head: La Revue Internationale
div.p: Le prochain numere de la "Revue Inter- nationale d'Egypte" ne le cedera en rien aux precedents. Il contiendra un travail de M. Alexandre Max de Zogheb sur "Alexandrie ancienne et moderne," un article de M. Legrain sur l'histoire de ses fouilles ou l'humour du conteur le dispute a la science de l'egyptolgue, le commencement des "Sou- venirs d'un engage volontaire" par Marcel Poi- lay bey, appeles a un vif succes cas l'auteur ra- conte ce qu'il a vu dans un recit pleiu de via et de couleur. Il s'agit de la defense de Belfore a laquelle M. Marcel Poilay prit part lors de la guerre franco-allemande. Signalons encore une nouvelle italienne de m. Frontali, des vers de M. Audibert, un jeune poete francais du plus bel avenir et enfin les lettres de l'etranger d"andre Besunier, de Gulielmo Ferrero, de Michel Delines, etc.

div.head: NATIONAL HOTELS & RESIDENCES
div.p: Nous publions aujourd'hui le prospectus d'emission de la "National Hotels and Resi- dences Co" Societe Anonyme recemment cons- tituee au Caire dans le but de creer ou ex- ploiter des Hotels, pensions, casinos, et tous etablissements similaires, et qui deja sotuelle- ment est proprietaire du "National Hotel" et de la "National Residence," rue Soliman Pachs, qui ont ete inangures le mois dernier et qui sont en pleine exploitation, sinsi que du Grand Hotel Casino d'Ain-Sofar (Mont Liban).

Comme on le voit, The National & Resi- dences Company, sa presente comme une tres belle affaire qui semble promettre des resultats brillants. Il suffit, du reste, de voir a quels cours sont actnellement cotes eu Bourse les titres des affaires de ce genre d'Egypte : ils valent environ deux fois et demi leur prix d'emission!
Tout le capital soit L.E. 200.000 divire en actions de L.E. 4 chscune aete souscrit au pair pas les fondateurs, qui en retrocedent 30.000 au public aux memes conditions.
Ils nous semble inutile d'insister sur l'avan- tage qu'il y a de pouvoir entrer au pair dans une telle affair, et il y a tout lieu de croire que l'emission sera un succes.

div.head: (Aujourd'hui a midi et demis)
div.p: Les cours sont en general soutenus, et des echanges ont en lieu en grand nombre en Banque Nationale, Agricole, Actious Credit Foncier et Estates.

La Bank of Abyssinia perd 1/8 a 7 1/8, la Behera 1/2 a 37 3/4, la Building 1/16 a 4 1/8, la Brasserie des Pyramides 4 fr. a 110, la Salt and Soda 1 shelling a 21/6, l'Alexandria Water 1/8 a 14 3/4, les Eaux du Caire 3 fr. a 116 et la Ramleh Railway 1/16 a 6 7/8.

Par contre, la Cansa di Scouto s'avance de 208 a 210, l'Investment de 1 3/32 a 1 1/8, le Trust de 1 5/33 a 1 7/32, l'Urbaine de 5 a 5 1/16, la Filature de 7/8 a 29/32, les Cotton Mills de 4/9 a 5 et les Sucreries de 28 a 29.
On voit par cette enumeration que le public semble reveoir de nouveau aux petites valeurs. La tendance generale rests cependant indecise.

div.head: Le Caire, 30 Novembre.
div.p: La reance d'aujourd'hui n'a pas ete tres billante comme prix, mais les echanges ont ete assez nombreux.

Le recul des prix est motive par la situation politque de l'Europe et aussi par les realisa- tions de fin de mois. Le marche est nerveux a l'exces. On desire acheter, profiter des cours recellement bas, mais on hesite.
La National Band a cloture a £25 7/16 pour l'ancienne et a £25 pour la nouvelles. Il est a ersin dresque baisse s'accentre demain pour les raisons que nous venons d'indiquer.
L'Agricultural aussi a faibli a £9 3/16 avec affaires relativement actives.

L'action Credit Foncier Egyptian persists a juste raison a se tenir beaucoup mieux ici qu'a Paris. Elle a fait 786 Frs. Les porteurs n'ont aucune inquietude a avoir; ils reverront cer- tainement des cours plus eleves a la premiere aclaircie.
Beaucoup d'achats en Egyptian Estates a £1 3/8-- Bonne valenr, elle est a anivre tout a gagner, rien a perdre.
Les Hotels re presentent aux environs des cours d'hier eoit a £10 1/2 les Nungovich, a £2 13/16 a 7/8 les Baehler, et a £5 1/8 a 3/16 les Upper.

Les Omnibus du Caire s'inscrivent a £14 1/2. Nous serious bien surpris si nous demeuriors longtemps a ce cours. Les resultats du dernier exercice sont aussi bons que ceux du precedent et le dividende sera tres probablement aussi omunerateur que celui de l'annee dernier.
Eucomme la loudeur ne devrait pass tenir longtemps si on examinait la position de beau- coup de noz societes.
Mais les facilities d'achat, a son allez 1

div.head: SIR W. WILLCOCKS' SCHEME AND THE BAGDAD RAILWAY. GERMAN OPINION.
div.p: The significance and details of Sir William Willcocks’ scheme for reconstructing the an- cient system of irrigation works in Mesopota- mia were discussed on Friday week at Berlin at an important meeting of the German Asiati Society. Dr. Wiedemann suggested that a rail way should be built without farther delay from Basra to Bagdad. No useful purpose, he argued: could possibly by served by postponing work on that section, which would open up to cultivation the most fruitful part of Mesopo- tamia, until after the completion of the railway connecting Bagdad with the north.

Here Rashdau, of the German Diplomatic Service, observed that Dr. Wiedemann’s pro- posal had already been considered. It was abandoned in deference to the interests of Turkey, which required that the railway should be built from north to south in order that the mobilisation of its troops might be accelerated, and also to furnish the Con- stantinople authorities with the means of en- forcing obedience on the Kurds.

He warned his hearers not to cherish op- timistic views regarding the speedy prolonga- tion of the railway. The country traversed hitherto was of a comparatively easy character, but the next sections offered great engineer- ing difficulties, quite apart from the disor- dered state of their administration. Who, he asked, was to provide the money required for the continuation of the enterprise ? Tur- key could not, because the foreign Powers, and particularly Great Britain, had been ren- dered suspicious by the fantastic political views imprudently aired by German writers, and had refused to assent to any increase in the Turkish Customs, with the object of producing the requisite revenue.
Herr Rashdan also urged that German manufacturers, merchants, and architects should now employ their time in creating large German interests and values in Mesopotamia.

Dr. Vosberg Reckow observed that the main significance of the Bagdad Railway for Ger- many's oversea policy must consist in the circumstance that it would provide a new highway to Asia, and thus be of political importance to the whole world. It would be quite easy, he said, to block the Suez Canal for a considerable time. Moreover, the Suez Canal was in control of the British, and it was absolutely necessary that another over- land and oversea route should be opened to Asia.

Dr. Wiedemann did not agree with the argu- ment that the Bagdad Railway would be of vast importance as a means of communication with Asia. The Siberian Railway he remarked, had not acquired the importance with which anticipation had invested it as a means of pro- moting international traffic in goods. It had merely exercised a certain effect on passenger traffic to the Far East, by compelling compa- nies to reduce their tariffs. The Bagdad Rail- way, except in times of war, would fulfil its chief function in fostering communication be- tween the interior and the coasts. A railway joining Basra with Bagdad would be a most profitable undertaking, for it would give an immense impetus to the culture of cotton.

Professor Otto Warburg, whose botanical studies in the tropics have earned for him an international reputation, argued that the Bag- dad Railway would be of incalculable value economically, and especially for the European cotton industries. He observed that the hopes cherished in Germany of cultivating sufficient cotton for the needs of the Empire in Africa were illusory. The one country which was suited for the growth of cotton was Mesopo- tamia, and the northern portion of Syria. The realisation of Sir William Willcocks's project would open up, at an expense of twenty millions stoning, two millions of hectares to cultivation, but there were at least two more millions of hectares in those regions where artificial irrigation would be unnecessary, and where cotton was already grown in small quantities. A German company had achieved very good results in the south of Asia Minor.

Professor Warburg suggested that in- ternational colonisation society should be formed to acquire certain rights of adminis- tration and jurisdiction in the territories to be traversed by the Bagdad Railway, and to colonise those territories with a labouring population numerous enough to render practic- able the cultivation of cotton on a large scale. If such a society could be formed it would be comparatively an easy matter to find the money necessary for the reconstruction of the ancient system of canals, and for assisting settlers to attain economical prosperity. “In this way alone,” concluded Professor Warburg, "will it be possible for European cotton in- dustries to liberate themselves from the tyranny of America. The problem is one that affects the entire European Continent, and it must be solved, unless Europe is prepared to abandon its cotton industries."

div.head: MEDICAL DISEASES OF EGYPT
div.p: The first volume of Dr. Sandwith's work, published by Henry Kimpton, London, deals mainly with infectious diseases. The value of the work is greatly increased by the free expression of personal opinion given by the author, which, in view of Dr. Sandwith's many years of Egyptian experience, renders the book invaluable' to “Egyptian students of medicine —and newly appointed English doctors—with- out any knowledge of what sort of diseases they are likely to meet among natives.” At the same time the author has taken great trouble over his references, a list of which is given after each disease, and has endeavoured suc- cessfully, we think to put before his readers a compendium of the knowledge and the various views on the diseases of Egypt.

The book is well printed and the articles on the various diseases are easy and pleasant reading. Occasionally we come across an opi- nion with which we are not in agreement, as for instance in the article on enteric fever (page 71), where the author states: "the pangs of hunger are only felt by those convalescents who have undergone a mild case, for after a long bout of fever the individual is too exhausted to be hungry.” Our own personal experience is distinctly contrary to this. On page 114, in his article on infectious jaundice, Dr. Sandwith passes a formidable sentence on our great port town : "the drains of Alexan- dria, constructed before the English Occupa- tion by ignorant engineers, remain a disgrace to that prosperous city, and when they are thoroughly reformed and house sanitation taken in hand infectious jaundice will prob- ably disappear.” Errors are few—on page 125 we notice in lines 8 and 9 a statement about the British army of which the sense is not clear.

We notice in page 152 a most excellent table giving the differential diagnosis of in- fluenza and dengue. This table should be most useful, as all practitioners know the difficulty sometimes experience in arriving at a certain opinion in such doubtful cases. Two of the most interesting articles in this volume are on plague and pellagra. The historical and prac- tical article on plague occupies 59 pages and has over 40 references given of the measures adopted in Egypt for dealing with this disease. The arti- cle on pellagra is excellent. It is a matter which Dr. Sandwith has made his own and the disease is investigated carefully from every point of view, and notes on no less than seven cases are given fully. On page 312 are the measures recommended to the Government by Dr. Sandwith for dealing with the disease, which are moderate and practical, though we fear it will be difficult to deal with the cases mentioned in paragraph 2, where he states that poor peasants grow their own maize and eat the "worst cobs which they cannot sell." The opinion expressed on page 312 is well worthy of notice : "Of all endemic disease to which Egypt is subject I believe pellagra to be the most important."

Without expressing absolute agreement with all the statements contained in this volume, we would cordially recommend it to all interested in Egyptian medical matters, as a valuable compendium of modern knowledge on the subject.

div.head: PROSPECTUS
div.p: La Societe a pour principal objet l'exploitation du National Hotel, de la National Residence recemment creed au Caire et du Grand Hotel de Sofar, a Alu-Sofar (Mont-Liban), que la Societe a acheter.

Le National Hotel nouvellement construit au quartier Ismailieh a ete inaugure ces jours derniers. Il est deja en pleine exploitation et l'on peut esperer, d'apres les arrangements conlcus, qu'il sera plein du 15 Decembre au 31 Mars. La Direction eu a ete confide a M. Ch. Bauer, dont la longue experience l'a recommende particulierement au choix des Administrateurs.

La National Residence, annexe de l'Hotel, compend des appartements meubles composes de chambres, salons, cabinets de toilette etc., loues a l'annee. Les contrats passes a ce jour assureut un revenu considerable pour l'annee, revenu qui sera augmente du chiffre des locations encore a conclure.
Le National Hotel et la National Residence seront ouverts toute l'annee.
En ete la direction et une partie du personnel du National Hotel se transporteront au Grand Hotel de Sofar.

Cette station sitnee a 1350 metres d'altitude dans le Mont-Liban est pour ainsi dire aussi populaire en Egypte qu'en Syrie. Chaque annee les Egyptians s'y rendeut, pendant la saison, en nombre toujours plus grand; c'est aussi le rendez-vous de toutes les notabilite des regions avoisinantes.

Le Grand Hotel de Sofar et le Casino diriges jusqu'ini par des personnes sans expe- rience rapportaient neamoins un revenu annuel de 20 a 25%. Eutre les mains de la Societe cette entreprise est appelee au plus grand avenir.

La Soceite a'efforcers egalement de doter la localite des attractions qui pourront lui attirer une plus nombreuse clientele. On vient de decouvrer une nouvelle source d'eau ferrugineuse et la constuction d'un etablissement thermal est a l'etude.
Des arrangement out ete faita pour facilitier le voyage aux residents egyptiens. Grace aux accords conclus on pourra dorenavant, se reudre du Caire a Ain Sofar en 24 heures, sans arret a Beyrouth.
On peut so procurer le Prospectus et le Bulletin de Souscription a l'Anglo-Egyptian Bank, au Caire et a Alexandrie.

div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompany- ing description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera, and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uni- formly warm than many other places in Europe Many people leave Egypt fartoo early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list showing the time oc- cupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
They are as follows:-
The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 4 days. The short ones are as follows:—

The steamers, of the P.&0. North German Lloyd, Orient and Messageriea Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, and Bibby Lines are also excellent, and their steamers, are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said, can now be made without change in 4.5 hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.
The most expensive but quickest through Continental routes are by P.&O. Brindisi express from Port 8aid, and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers “Osiris" and “Isis” to Brindisi. One of these leaves port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the, Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The, direct route to Sicily is by the Florio- Rubattino Co.’s steamers which leave Alex- andria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMENA, one of the most charm- ing and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.’s steam- ers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will tike you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing inte- rest, whilst the local promenades and excur- sions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallom- brosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog- wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; hero there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba).—The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy’s most an- cient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medie- val churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the in- comparable Campo Santo filled with its won- derful tombs.
Prom Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monu- mental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is SALSOMAG- GIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Donino and in half-an-hour yoa are at Salsomaggiore.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY (Continued) and The ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange ; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of anyf other sea port. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea, no hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Cam- paniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.
Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes.
COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza :

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and -three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs."

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charm- ingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprino.and M. Generoso.

LOCARNO, may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of lake Maggiore has a mild climate and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interest- ing paintings, “Entombment," by Ciseri, and ‘Tho Flight into Egypt,” by Bramantion.
LUCERNE—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps.
In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous.

The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgen- stock and Sonnenberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne, to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse

A delightful exeption from Lucerne is that to ENGELBERG. Take boat to Stansstad and from Stansstad it is about 1 hour and 40 min. by Electric Railway, with delightful scenery en route. The ascent of Titlis, is made from here, and the panoramic view of the Alps is grand; extending from Monte Rosa to the Black Forest, and from the Santis to the Matterhorn.

THE BERNESE OBERHAND.-INTER- LAKEN a favourite summer resort and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Giessbach, Trummelbath and Staubbach. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed.

CHATEAU D’OEX. 3,500 ft above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alex- andria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co.

If possible tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara for which a special train is run from Athens.
It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.

div.head: Chemins de Fer et Telegraphes de l’Etat Egyptian
AVIS
div.p: L’Administration des Chemins de fer Egyptiens a l’honneur de faire savoir an Public qa'une adjudication aura lieu le ll Decembre 1905 pour la location des parcelles de terrain ci-dessous designees a l’effet d’y installer des Kiosques mobiles sans etage a l’usage de buffets, savoir:
Les soumissionnaires doivent fiaire une offre pour chaque parcelle separement, et le prix offert doit etre indique par metre carre et par mois.

Los offres doivent etre faites sur papier timbre de P.T. 3 adressees a M. le Directeur General de 1’Administration des Chemins de fer de l’Etat, sous double enveloppe, et sous pli ca- ohete et remises avant le 11 Ddcembre a midi.
L’enveloppe interieuro doit porter la sus- cription :
La location oommencera le ler Janvier 1906 et prendra fin le 31 Decembre 1908.
Le modele de contrat de bail est depose au bureau de M. l'Ingenieur en Chef de la'Voje et des Travaux et a chacune des gares des loca- lites sus-mentionnees, a la disposition des sou- missionnaires.
L'Administration se reserve le droit de n’ac- cepter aucune des offres qui lui seront faites.

Toute offre doit etre accompagnee, a titre de depot, d'une valour de LE 10, soit en une quittance de la Caisse Centrale des Chemins de fer, ou en un cheque sur une Banqua Ce depot restera acquis a l’Administration si le soumissionuaire, devenant adjudicataire d’un terrain, n'en prend pas possession.
L’Administration se reserve le droit de juger s’il y a lieu ou non d’assurer le recours des voisins. Le locataire devra se soumettre a la decision de l’Administration.
Il devra egalement prendre a sa charge les frais de gardiennage du kiosque demontable pour buffet par lui installe.

Le soumitsiounnaire devra, dans sa soumis- sion, declarer avoir pris connaissanoe des clau- ses du contrat, siusi que des lieux et s’engager a faire les demarches necessaires en vue d'ob- tenir la roksa reglementaire.
Le Caire le 35 Novembre 1905.

div.head: IRRIGATION ENGINEERING.
div.p: By, Sir Hanburt Brown, K.C.M.G.. late Inspector-General of Irrigation in Lower Egypt, and formerly in Upper Egypt.
v.

The Assouan reservoir of the Nile supple- ments a summer discharge in the river ; but in India there are storage reservoirs formed by dams constructed across, gorges in the hills which entirely, furnish, the summer supply of the tracts depending on them without help from any associated river. In the preparation of the projects for such works as these, careful calculations of the rainfall and "flow off" of the catchment must be made, as there are no better means of arriving at the figures which represent the amount of water that will flow into the reservoir. In the case of the Nile storage the river discharges at the very site of the reservoir, for all seasons and for all years of varying levels, were known, so that the quantity of water available in any year for filling the reservoir could be calculated with much greater precision than is possible when the calculation has to be based on rainfall statistics and on an assumed proportion of “flow off.”

There is one more source of water supply deserving of mention in connection with irri- gation, namely, wells. It is estimated that in British India no less than 13 million acres are watered from wells, or more than 25 per cent of the whole irrigated area of India. So that this source has its importance, but from an agricultural point of view rather than from that of the engineer.

Mention has been made above of pumps as a means of artificially raising water tor irriga- tion on a comparatively small scale. In India pumping stations have hitherto taken no part in the irrigation of the country. But in Egypt pumps play an important part; and, at one time, 1883, it was proposed by the then Direc tor-General of Public Works to abandon all attempts to make the Delta Barrage do the work of artificially raising the water level of the Nile to the extent necessary for the irriga- tion of the Delta, and to erect powerful pump- ing stations as a substitute. The cost of work- ing these stations was estimated at £250,000 a year. At this critical moment of Egyptian irri- gation Sir Colin Scott Monecrieff was given charge of it, and the question whether the Delta should depend for its irrigation on the barrage restored or on pumping stations, prac- tically rested with him to decide. Fortunately for Egypt he preferred the barrage, add forth- with took steps to make it do its work, and with complete success. The barrage costs less than £10.000 a year to maintain and regulate, and without any farther expense is capable of distributing any increased supply that may be provided to meet the growing area of cultiva- tion ; whereas the cost of lifting the water by pumps—estimated at £250,000 a year in 1883, before the development of the Delta that has taken place during the past twenty years— would increase with the quantity of water to be lifted, and fluctuate with the price of coal. Moreover, a war might at some time have cut off the coal supply, and Egypt's cotton, now worth £5,000,000 a year, would have been lost. The barrage was undoubtedly the best servant to engage in the interests of Egypt. It has, since its restoration, become so efficient, and so unmistakably the proper instrument for the water distribution of the Delta, that one large pumping station, that had already been erected before Sir Colin's time, has since been dismantled and its engines and pumps transferred to another station which provides for the drainage of certain lands below sea level.

This instance is given to show that the merits of pumping stations, as an alternative method of raising water, have sometimes to be considered in working out a project of irrigation. At the present moment there is a scheme under construction in Madras for the irrigation of 50,000 acres by pumping, the lift being from 10ft. to 12ft.

Though the Government scheme of irriga- tion in Egypt dispenses with the aid of pumps —with the exception of an unimportant sur- vival at one point of the Delta-still a con- siderable area of its cultivation depends for its irrigation on pumping stations owned by private estates and individuals, as there is a large proportion of the cultivated area which is above the reach of “free flow" from the canals.

As a conclusion to the consideration of the points which affect the drawing up of a canal scheme, a few words more concerning drainage may be added to what has already been said about its importance. The subject must not be set on one side to receive consideration after the canals have been made, and until it forces itself into prominence by the evils that result from its neglect The natural drainage lines, as has been said, should not be obstructed. They follow, as a rule, the depressions which lie between the ridges on which the canals should be run. But if there be no decided depressions, or if the land is flat, drains should be dug on the most convenient alignment between the canals, and, in such a case, it is the distribution of the canals rather than the physical features of the ground which de- termines the position of the drains.

It is not an easy matter to decide what dimensions should be given to the drains. It is desirable, if the outfall allows, to keep the water surface in the drains 2ft. or 8ft. below soil. The maximum discharge which should be provided for will be proportional to the area to be drained and will depend on the rainfall as well as on the description of irriga- tion practiced. Rice land will discharge at least double the amount that ordinary crops do. In Egypt it was at one time assumed that one third of the water used for the irrigation of such crops as cotton and maize found its way into the drains, and 8 cubic metres a day

per acre of area commanded was considered to be the quantity that represented this third. But, though this allowance may be sufficient for the main drains, it is not enough for the branches. For on the main drains a fairly constant discharge is maintained as the average drainage of a large extent of country, as some branch drains may be discharging one day and some another, the ones that are dis- charging being balanced by those that have ceased discharging. But the branch drains dis- charge under different conditions, flowing and not flowing alternately for let us assume, equal periods. Consequently, as the maximum flow must be that which determines the drain sec- tion, and, accepting 8 cubic metres a day per acre served by the drain as the average run off, we must allow a section that will carry the same allowance in half time, that is, we must allow for a discharge at the rate of 16 cubic metres a day per acre. On the minor branches the discharge is still more fitful, and the allow- ance of section most be still greater. Now the maximum discharge allowed in the canals for purposes of irrigation has been usually calcu- lated at the rate of 25 cubic metres a day per acres of gross area, the drainage maximum in any drain should, therefore, be something less than this, and it would seem to be sufficient to make the main drain below the inflow of the lowest branch drain capable of carrying a discharge calculated at the rate of 8 cubic metres a day per acre of land draining into it; and to make the minor branches, at the other or upper extremity of the drained area, capable of carrying 18 cubic metres a day per acre, while the intermediate drains would be given a discharging capacity at the rate of 15, 12, and 10 cubic metres a day per acre according to their position on the drainage system to which they belonged. This example is given merely as a general illustration of the principle on which a drainage system should be designed, and not as laying down any details as to the amount of drainage which should be provided for, as different countries have different condi- tions which require to be met in each case.

div.head: NEW MILLS FOR EGYPTIAN COTTON.
div.p: A return has been prepared by Mr W. Tattersal giving the number of new ootton -spinning mills erected, or about to be erected, in Lancashire by limited liability companies. From this it appears that seven mills contain- ing 540,000 spindles using Egyptian cotton have got fully to work within the last few months, and an equal number of Egyptian yarn mills with 610,000 spindles have partly commenced. In addition to these, 16 mills, to contain 1,605,000 spindles, all of which will spin Egyptian cotton, are in course of erection, making a total of 30 mills and 2,755,000 spindles.

The number of new mills just commenced spinning American cotton is three, with 240.000 spindles, and there are in course of erection 24 additional mills for American yarn, which will hold 1,960,000 spindles, a total of 27 mills, and 2,200,000 spindles.
Summarised, the totals are as follows:—

The circular also points out that the increas- ed yam exports this year so far on the same ten months of 1904 are equal to the production of 12 average large sized factories (1,200,000 spindles) working full hours during the period named.

div.head: EGYPTIAN BANKS.
div.p: In a leaderette on the subject of Egyptian Banks, the “Financial Times" says: Although movements in the shares of Egyptian banks play rather a prominent part in the market for Egyptian securities, it must be understood that the decline recently seen in no way reflects upon the working of these concerns. Owing to the fact that a large Continental interest is attached to the development of Egypt, several of the newer banks, such as the National of Egypt and the Agricultural Bank of Egypt, have their capital in the form of "bearer" shares, which, of course, lenders speculation in them easier than in the English form of re- gistered shares. Speculators in Cairo and on the Continent would seem to have been dazzled by the great prosperity shown by Egypt of late years, and have pushed up the price of these shares to such a pitch that those well con- versant with business in the country have for a long time past considered that they were above the level which ordinary conditions should warrant their reaching. In consequence, many of the shares have been lifted from Europe, and have gone to Egypt, where the operators, relying upon loans from some of the purely local banks, have been carrying them as a speculation. When the usual pinch for money occasioned by the moving of the cotton crop was felt in the country, these speculators have found themselves in a rather awkward position, and, no doubt, they have had to throw over- board some of their holdings. This is the history of the present depression in the shares, and it does not in any way reflect upon the manage- ment of the concerns themselves.

div.head: London, Nov. 21.
div.p: Major D. K. E. Hall, A S.C., from service with the Egyptian Army, has been appointed second-in-command of the A.S.C. at Woolwich, in succession to Major A. E. Bramhall.

Among recent changes in the Sudan Ad- ministration, Major C. K. Hawker, Cold- stream Guards, and Captain A. Sutherland, Argyll and Sutherland Highlanders, have been appointed Governors of the Provinces of Suakin and Bahr-el-Ghazal, respectively.

As already intimated in these notes, Major C. L. Armitage, Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, second in command of the 1st Battalion at Victoria Barracks, Belfast, will shortly vacate that appointment under the age rules, to the regret of all ranks. Major H. O. D. Hickman, 2nd Battalion at Cairo, has been ordered home to join the 1st Battalion in anticipa- tion of taking up the appointment of second in command. Major Hickman joined the 19th Yorkshire Regiment in 1880, and was trans- ferred ten years later to the Inniskillings, in which he obtained his majority in February, 1900, whilst on active service. He saw ser- vice in the Nile Expedition of 1884-5 with the “Green Howards" (medal with clasp, and Khedive’s star), and whilst attached to the Egyptian Army, participated in the opera- tions of 1888 in the Sudan, including the action of Gemaizah (4th class Medjidieh, clasp) and he was with the 1st Battalion in its campaigning after the relief of Ladysmith, including the actions of Belfast and Lyden- berg and the operations in the Transvaal (medal with two clasps).

Lieutenant Colonel F.D.V. Wing, C.B., Royal Horse Artillery, who commanded the 69th Battery Royal Field Artillery at Talana Hill, the opening action of the Boer War, and in the defence of Ladysmith, has been selected for the command of the Lancashire Royal Field Artillery Militia.

Lieutenant R J. Collins, who has taken up the duties of aide-de-camp to the Sirdar, is a smart young officer of the Royal Berk- shire Regiment with a future. As an intelli- gence officer, and with the 2nd Battalion of his regiment, he did good work in the South African War, particularly in the arduous work near its close. He has been doing duty with the Khedive’s Army for some time.

The S.S. Sicilia will leave Southampton on Saturday next with about 1,000 troops— principally artillery and infantry drafts for batteries, companies, and battalion in the Pun- jab—on board for the port of Karachi, where the liner is due about the l8th prox.
The 5th Battalion Royal Garrison Regiment arrived at Liverpool today from Halifax, N.S., for disbandment

Captain the Hon. R F. Boyle will hoist his pennant as flag captain of the cruiser Levia- than at Portsmouth on the 5th prox., on which date the cruiser will be re-commis- sioned to carry the flag of Rear-Admiral the Hon. Hedworth Lambton, C.V.O., C.B. com- manding the Third Cruiser Squadron attached to the Mediterranean Fleet

It is reported from New York that when Prince Louis of Battenburg was ready to leave with the Second Cruiser Squadron for Gibral- tar, some one thousand of his handymen were missing—the temptations of New York being too much for them.

Doctors have differed since the science of medicine was first invented, and we might leave them to fall out, to the end of the chapter, were it not for the mischievous results that sometimes follow. There is a controversy rag- ing at this moment between the champions and opponents of a new scheme for minimising, if not eliminating, enteric fever from troops both in peace and war. An eminent civil doctor, Dr. Leigh Canney, of Assouan, has established a theory that with a proper system of sterilising drinking water the terrible outbreaks of disease might be practically avoided. It only needs organisation, a little elaborate; perhaps, but perfectly feasible, by means of which pure water can always be within reach of the soldiers, in camp and quarters, on the march, and in the fighting line. Carts with water on the boil are to be perpetually available, and their presence near the front is deemed of im- portance only second to that of bringing up ammunition. The principle was, as a matter of fact, accepted soon after it was propounded, and the system seemed likely to be introduced in our Army a couple of years ago. But the proposal has hung fire ever since, mainly because it did not commend itself to our Army Medical Advisory Board. The only reason given is that the authorities contend that the enteric bacillus is not invariably water-borne. There are other avenues of infection, such as air, dust, and flies, although it is not denied that water is the principal. In other words, because opinions an not quite agreed on the sources of the disease no steps are to be taken to combat it when it appears, and we shall assuredly he overtaken by a similar epidemic as in the Boer War, with the same lethal con- sequences . It must be accepted as a reproach to us that the Japanese have shown a more enlightened spirit and carried out the essentials of the sterilising scheme in their recent great campaign.

A good deal of fun has been poked at the Army Council for their late order with regard to polo playing. It can hardly be possible that the game is so little understood by the rulers of the British Army that it is found necessary to forbid officers to ride their chargers when playing it. A polo pony might and has been need as a charger, but the contrary is hardly possible. We shall hear next that the automo- bile, of which there are some now on public charge, or the elephant, is tabooed. The atti- tude of the authorities towards polo is rather strange. This last order grew out of a humble request from those interested in the game that the War Office should express its wishes and lay down rules and regulations for polo. The answer was a contemptuous repudiation of the game entirely; it did not care for polo or recognise it in any way. It did not quite like to forbid it—that would have been too retro- grade in regard to a sport which is universally admitted to have its uses far beyond mere amusement. The game develops high qualities, skill, and readiness of hand and eye, great promptitude in action, and encourages fine horsemanship. It may, of course, lead to extravagance—prohibitory prices are sometimes paid for ponies - but this could be regulat- ed by authority, and the advantages gained are far in excess of the possible drawbacks.

div.head: CREDIT LYONNAIS
div.p: Société Anonyme
Capital 250,000,000 de francs
Entièrement Versés
Agences d'Égypte:
Alexandrie, Le Caire, Port-Said
Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que:
Ouverture de comptes courants contre dépôts de valeurs;
Emission de traites et chèques, émission de lettres de Crédit, paiement par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France et de l'étranger;
Garde de titres;
Recourvement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger;
Le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds ou un compte de dépôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe aux taux suivants:
2% aux bons de 1 an et au-delà.

L’EGYPTIAN GAZETTE est en vent dans les rues du Caire tous les soirs a h.80, excepte les dimanches et jours feries. Le journal est aussi en cente aux gares du Caire, d'Alexandrie, de Tantah, de Du manhour de Kafr-Zayat et de Zugarig. Pris numeric du jour, 1 P.T.
